comments:
I've installed last 0.4.9 version and it was working fine until I had to install new Subclipse feature from the update manager.

So, after update manager restarted Eclipse, Mylar tasklist got no tasks at all, but I got all those tasks back after restarted Eclipse one more time.

Here are few things I found in a .log

Created an attachment (id=35338)
some weird error popups

BTW, on a second restart I got whole bunch of error popups. Those things should not be done in such way...

That error in the stack trace should not cause any bad behavior, but I have fixed that issue.  I will look into the popups, but it looks like you have lost the repositories?  I need more info to figure out what the bug is and would like to do so asap. 

Is Mylar starting up properly?  If the task list is blank it propbably isn't.  When you restart, does the bahvior persist?
Btw, when debugging this consider uninstalling all previous versions of Mylar if the task list continues to fail to start.  Let me know how it goes.
Mik, as I said, all tasks get back after second restart, but I am getting all those popups on every restart since then.

It looks like some old bugzilla entries I've created before migrating to new repository support somehow got recovered, so I am getting those popups when refresh sync on restart is trying to refresh them. There is no way to tell which entries are broken and I can't change their urls too. I guess I have to delete those entries.

Generally it would be better to mark those entries with special decoration instead of bringing up a popup dialogs.

Good, that makes sense: 0.4.9 did had a major cleanup on tasklist serialization which would cause these tasks to become a part of synchronization, etc.  

I like the decoration suggestion: we can simply replace the blue repository icon with an error if the task has been 'orphaned'.  That would also allow us to get rid of that misleading dialog.

In the meantime, I hope that you can find those bad entries.  If you can't let me know and I'll make a dev build with a dialog that prints out the label.

(In reply to comment #6)
> Good, that makes sense: 0.4.9 did had a major cleanup on tasklist serialization
> which would cause these tasks to become a part of synchronization, etc.  

But it still does not explain where did those tasks go after restart done by update manager...

> I like the decoration suggestion: we can simply replace the blue repository
> icon with an error if the task has been 'orphaned'.  That would also allow us
> to get rid of that misleading dialog.

It would be a good idea to allow to edit the task url or to choose another repository for those tasks.

> In the meantime, I hope that you can find those bad entries.  If you can't let
> me know and I'll make a dev build with a dialog that prints out the label.

It's ok. I can delete those manually or get rid of the wole folder.
TODO: when fixing this we need to disallow changing the URL of a repository and to provide a "rename" type action which updates the handle of every corresponding query and task context.
Changing the URL of a repository now causes handles to be refactored (in the tasklist and in the paths of stored contexts).
